subject: Huge mem usage during tunnel type driver initialization
commit_message:
Huge mem usage during tunnel type driver initialization

Currently if large ranges are specified in ml2_conf.ini for
tunnel ID ranges like 'vni_ranges = 1001:16777215', the neutron
service will fail to start. This happens for gre type as well.
On a node with memory pressure the service may bail out with
MemoryError. This is due to high memory use associated with
the use of 'set' python primitive. In the TunnelTypeDriver's
initialization, during sync_allocations() 'set' is used to
build a unique range of tunnel IDs, the list of IDs to remove
and missing list for allocation. When large ranges are
specified this leads to very high memory use as the entire
sequential range is built out in memory to form union,
difference etc. This patch addresses this by operating on
ranges directly as they are received from configuration.
Without building out the entire set/list of sequential numbers,
it de-duplicates the ranges in the list and builds the list to
remove and allocate. This change brings down the memory usage
in the order of GBs and finishes initialization within the
same time, or even better.

As mentioned in the bug there are many other scaling issues to
consider before neutron can handle such large ranges. These
issues are not addressed in this patch. This patch only reduces
the memory use during type driver initialization. With this
patch the vmem usage of neutron-server is within 600-700MB range,
whereas with the 'set' it was climbing to > 1.5-2GB. With this
change q-svc service takes 25-30 mins to start completely on a
4GB VM running devstack, when a range of 1:16777215 is specified.

Change-Id: Ie0702c0363492ba8fbc240688635a53857c835fd
Closes-Bug: 1426904
Related-Bug: 1326634

subject: Fix the deadlock occuring on task executions
commit_message:
Fix the deadlock occuring on task executions

* When inserting multiple task executions we sometimes got into
  a dead lock where transaction A would wait for an exclusive
  (write) lock on 'unique_key' of some task execution and
  transaction B would hold that lock on 'unique_key' but waiting
  for a gap lock for primary key holding by transaction A.
  Solution: remove 'unique_key' column and expand 'id for
  task executions where in case of 'join' tasks (and any tasks
  with preconditions) we just store a unique key identifying
  a certaint join task in a certain workflow. By doing that
  we eliminate two locks that transactions can possibly compete
  for and leave just one (primary key).

TODO:
* DB migration for DB schema changes

subject: Optimize Scheduler DB schema
commit_message:
Optimize Scheduler DB schema

* Dropped a composite index for ('execution_time', 'processing'),
  left only 'execution_time' because 'processing' is boolean
  and indexing booleans doesn't give any performance improvement
* On a high load MySQL sometimes goes into a deadlock when
  we were using unique key constraint for (unique_key, processing)
  on 'insert' and 'update' operations. It was possible to reproduce
  this kind of deadlock locally in 3 MySQL consoles where one TX
  was doing 'update ... where' and two others were doing 'insert'.
  This composite unique key constraint was dropped and replaced
  with composite primary key ('key', 'processing'). In this case
  the deadlock never happens (seems like PK are handled more
  efficiently).

TODO:
* There's still an issue with duplicate entries for delayed calls
  on operations 'update ... where' when running more than one
  scheduler. It's solvable by either using a buck update
  operation or slightly smarter handling of such error. On
  Postgres some special handling is required because it always
  switch a TX into 'rollback-only' mode on any SQL error.

commit_message:
Simplify manage-migration spec by introducing database triggers

By introducing database triggers to this specification, we can vastly
simplify the overall implementation and operator experience and skip
straight to zero downtime. There's no need for the operator to manage
any metadata in the database about the state of the migration, beyond
what sqlalchemy-migrate will do for us, and there's no need to write
versionedobjects for each possible object state during a live migration.
Hopefully that will all translate to fewer bugs.

On the downside, it means that we have to manually write triggers, which
may be need to be specifically tailed for each of our supported
databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, and SQLite).

subject: Generate API report tooling
commit_message:
Generate API report tooling

NB: The code here is not pretty and could use some love.
However there's many more pressing things to do, so perhaps
this can be revisited later need be (as we agreed during the
neutron-lib meeting [3]).

This patch adds a python and bash script to our tools that can be
run during tox/gate to generate python public API reports as
discussed during out neutron lib meeting [2][3]. The idea is that
this tool can be run to generate a public API report that we can
use to release note our neutron-lib releases [3].

There are 2 main approaches for extracting an API from python
source; (a) loading the source an using inspect based modules
to reflect the API and (b) reading the source without loading
it and parsing API signatures from raw source text. In addition
a hybrid approach can be taken with uses a combination of

This script uses preprocessing and inspection to permit python
source to be loaded (without its dependencies) and inspected.
The inspected source's public signatures are collected and
stored in a JSON format that defines the public API for the
inspected source. JSON API reports can also be compared to
determine what public APIs have changed, added, removed or
stayed the same.

The high level approach for generating an API is as follows:
- Copy the source directory tree to a temp staging location.
- Replace all imports in the staging source with mock imports
so that modules can be loaded without dependencies.
- Walk the source, dynamically loading modules and inspecting
them.
- Build a representation of the inspection including public
signatures. This include public functions, methods, and
variables. Only simple/scalar variable (module or class attrs)
values are tracked at present.
- Format the representation into a JSON format that can
be saved to a file and later used for comparison.

For a sample of the current output, see [1].

This patch also adds a standalone tox target called 'api-report'
that can be used to generate a new API report against the
current change. Note that tox target explicitly specifies the
neutron-lib version to do the api diff against and thus will need
updating per neutron-lib release.

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/526626/
[2] http://goo.gl/9Xpi4K
[3] http://goo.gl/LlAjX7

subject: Clear primary roles during upgrade of nodes
commit_message:
Clear primary roles during upgrade of nodes

This patch clears primary_roles of a node during its reassignment as a
part of an upgrade. Without this fix it is possible to have several
primary roles in a seed cluster during the upgrade. This race condition
leads to some failed deployments during the upgrade. As a result primary
roles have to be cleared during the reassignment of nodes. That allows
to assign primary roles on appropriate nodes rely on the internal logic.
